newsitem.title: USA: Mitchell sets Louisiana Chalk pipeline.
newsitem.headline: Mitchell sets Louisiana Chalk pipeline.

text.p: Mitchell Energy & Development Corp said it and Chesapeake Energy Corp plan to build a natural gas pipeline and gathering system in south-central Louisiana to move natural gas from Chesapeake's Austin Chalk Trend wells to Enron Corp's Eunice Plant in Acadia Parish.

Mitchell said it and Chesapeake agreed in principle to form a joint venture to build a 40-mile, 20-inch pipeline and a 40-mile gathering system capable of handling up to 250 million cubic feet of natural gas daily.
In a separate action, Chesapeake and Enron have reached an agreement whereby Enron will expand its Eunice natural gas processing facility to handle Chesapeake's gas.
Mitchell said construction of the pipeline is expected to be completed in the spring of 1997, with the first operational section completed by the end of this year.
It said the expected cost of the first phase pipeline and gathering facilities is $25 million and has been named the Louisiana Chalk Gathering System.

The completed pipeline will have sufficient capacity to move natural gas from wells drilled by Chesapeake and other third-party producers in Rapides, Allen, Evangeline, Avoyelles and St. Landry parishes to the Eunice area.

"Based upon our agreement with Chesapeake, we will immediately proceed to de-bottleneck Enron's Eunice Gas Processing Plant and Fractionator to accommodate the large increase in NGL volumes to be recovered from Chesapeake's gas," said Enron Liquid Services Corp.
